blurb: The Eagles are loaded, even without quarterback Carson Wentz as their opening week starter.
The window may be closing for the Patriots’ dynasty. But as long as Bill Belichick and Tom Brady are there, the Pats are legitimate Super Bowl contenders.
The Steelers should again be one of the most dynamic offenses in the NFL … if running back Le’Veon Bell shows up prior to the season opener.
The Vikings boast perhaps the league’s premier defense. Will Kirk Cousins be the last piece of the puzzle in Minnesota?
The Jaguars’ defense is dominant, but is Blake Bortles good enough to contribute to a Super Bowl run.
The Rams owned the offseason, and now Aaron Donald is back as well. Look out below.
Without Mark Ingram, who is suspended for the first four games, it’ll be up to second-year standout Alvin Kamara to produce a dazzling sequel.
The Super Bowl will be in Atlanta this season. Will the Falcons be there, too?
Aaron Rodgers is healthy and happy, after earning one heck of a paycheck this offseason. As he goes, so go the Packers.
The Panthers know what they have in veteran quarterback Cam Newton. The question is whether their offensive line will keep him upright.
There is reason for optimism in Los Angeles, and not just because of the Rams and Lakers. Good luck finding a more established pass-rushing duo than Joey Bosa and Melvin Ingram III.
The Patrick Mahomes era has begun in Kansas City. Now, we’ll all find out if the second-year quarterback is ready.
Deshaun Watson and J.J. Watt are back, and the Texans may be primed for the playoffs.
Has the addition of Khalil Mack pushed the Bears into the playoff picture?
Eli Manning may not have anything left in the tank. But considering Saquon Barkley’s arrival and Odell Beckham Jr.’s big deal, it might not matter, either.
Ezekiel Elliott is the primary focus offensively, but for the first time in years, Dallas has considerable questions along its offensive line.
No Richard Sherman. No Kam Chancellor. No Michael Bennett. No Earl Thomas (for now). No telling what these Seahawks will look like in 2018.
The 49ers closed the 2017 season with five consecutive wins. But was that a mirage or a sign of things to come?
Quarterback Case Keenum will attempt to resurrect the Broncos after an unexpected 5-11 tumble in 2017.
It's first-year head coach Matt Patricia's job to turn around a group that finished 27th in total defense last season. Good luck.
Jon Gruden is back! But Khalil Mack isn't. The Raiders could be gearing up for an eventual rebuild.
The Ravens, who kicked off the preseason by beating the Bears in the Hall of Fame Game, are the only team in the NFL to enjoy a 5-0 preseason. We'll see if that matters on Sunday.
The Titans made the playoffs in 2017, won a playoff game and then fired their head coach. I'm still trying to make sense of that whole situation.
The good news for Arizona is that running back David Johnson is back. The bad news is that Sam Bradford is the Cardinals' starting quarterback.
The Bengals finished 31st in rushing offense and 27th in passing offense last season. And if you can't run, and you can't pass ... you get the idea.
Andrew Luck's return is a bright spot for Indianapolis. The rest of its roster is not.
The Browns are still the Browns. Moving on.
The Bills announced this week that they will start Nathan Peterman at quarterback for the season opener. This does not inspire confidence.
The Washington offense, which lost running back Derrius Guice for the season, looked dreadful during the preseason. We'll see if Alex Smith and Adrian Peterson can change that.
Quarterback Jameis Winston will be suspended for the Buccaneers' first three games. Tampa Bay could be in for a long season.
Sam Darnold will be the Jets' starting quarterback on Sunday. The good news is that his first three opponents are the Lions, the Dolphins and the Browns.
Well, at least the fans still live in Miami. That should provide some consolation in 2018.
The Eagles used the "Philly Special" to pick up another win. Real original.
Tom Brady threw for 277 yards and three touchdowns last weekend, despite having a no-name wide receiver corps. In other words, it's business as usual.
The punishing Minnesota defense forced four San Francisco turnovers in its season opener. That isn't a fluke.
Todd Gurley and Jared Goff were both sharp in the Rams' season opener. When they're rolling like that, who can stop them?
acksonville's offense was underwhelming already. If Leonard Fournette has to miss any time with a hamstring injury, the Jaguars might be in trouble.
Carolina's defense held the Dallas Cowboys to just eight points, 232 total yards and 94 rushing yards last week. That's an impressive start.
The Patrick Mahomes era kicked off with four touchdown passes in an impressive 38-28 win over the Chargers. All aboard the hype train.
The Broncos' pass rush is still fearsome, but Case Keenum needs to be better if the Broncos are going to make a serious run.
The Falcons scored just 10 points in five red zone trips last week. Matt Ryan, Julio Jones and Co. have work to do.
How impressive is a 47-3 win when it comes over the lowly Bills? We'll find out when the Ravens meet the Bengals on Thursday.
If Aaron Rodgers has to miss any time with a knee injury, the ship might sink in Green Bay.
Saquon Barkley and Odell Beckham did their part in the Giants' season-opening loss to Jacksonville. Now Eli Manning needs to do his.
The Chargers didn't have Joey Bosa last weekend ... and it showed.
Le'Veon, Le'Veon, wherefore art thou, Le'Veon?
Ryan Fitzpatrick threw for 417 yards and four touchdowns on the road against the Saints. You figure it out.
For the first time since Dec. 24, 2016, the Browns didn't lose. But they didn't win, either.
The Bears led the Packers 20-0 late in the third quarter last weekend. They're 0-1. That's Aaron Rodgers.
Maybe the Bengals' offense really is improved. Or maybe we just think so because they picked on the hapless Colts.
Deshaun Watson's return from a torn ACL wasn't enough for the Texans to upright the Patriots in New England.
Doug Baldwin is down and the Seahawks' pass rush is non-existent. Oh, and that offensive line has to protect Russell Wilson from Khalil Mack on Monday night.
Jimmy Garoppolo completed just 45.5 percent of his passes and threw three interceptions against Minnesota. Not exactly how you make good on that massive offseason contract.
The Saints gave up 48 points and lost to the Bucs -- yes, the Bucs -- at home. Did anyone see that coming?
Dallas, which has made its name by running the football, managed just 94 rushing yards in a loss to the Panthers. The pressure's on Dak Prescott.
After throwing a pick-six on his first NFL pass, Sam Darnold settled down and led the Jets to a road win. So far, so good.
Derek Carr's three interceptions helped spoil Jon Gruden's Black Hole homecoming in Oakland.
Miami's game last weekend lasted more than seven hours because of weather delays. But hey, a win's a win.
Adrian Peterson provided a blast from the past in Washington's season opener, producing 166 total yards and a touchdown in the win over Arizona.
Marcus Mariota's status is unknown with an elbow injury. Good luck with Blaine Gabbert, Titans fans!
Andrew Luck is back! Unfortunately the can't be said for Edgerrin James and Reggie Wayne.
The Cardinals produced just 213 total yards and six points in Sam Bradford's Arizona debut. Josh Rosen better start warming up.
Matt Stafford threw four interceptions and the Lions were blown out at home by a rookie quarterback making his first career start. Not a great first impression for Matt Patricia.
After making the playoffs in 2017, the Bills lost 47-3 to the Baltimore Ravens last weekend. It's only a matter of time until Buffalo is on the clock.
The Rams have outscored their opponents 77-13 in their first two games.
Jacksonville made a statement with a decisive home win over New England last week. If Blake Bortles is good, the Jaguars are great.
Patrick Mahomes has thrown 10 touchdown passes with zero interceptions in his first two games. Who needs Alex Smith, anyway?
I have to be honest: I didn't see this coming. With Ryan Fitzpatrick as their quarterback, the Bucs have beaten two of the NFL's preseason favorites to start their season.
The Vikings left Green Bay with a tie last weekend, but they also saw quarterback Kirk Cousins at his best, and that's a good sign going forward.
The bad news is that Philadelphia lost to the surprising Bucs last weekend. The good news: quarterback Carson Wentz is back.
The Patriots allowed 377 passing yards and four touchdown passes to Blake Bortles last weekend. You read that right.
As long as the Packers have arguably the best quarterback on Earth, they'll be a playoff contender.
Andy Dalton has thrown six touchdown passes and just one interception in his first two games. But the Colts and Ravens aren't exactly prime competition, either.
The Broncos led the Raiders for exactly six seconds last Sunday. Six seconds were enough.
In a match up of Matt Ryan and Cam Newton, the quarterback who ran for two touchdowns last weekend was Ryan. Really.
The Dolphins are 2-0, but those wins have come against the Titans (without Marcus Mariota) and the Jets. I remain unconvinced.
The Panthers' offense is essentially all Cam Newton and Christian McCaffrey. The latter caught 14 -- yes, 14 -- passes last weekend from the running back position.
Phillip Rivers completed 85 percent of his passes in a win over the lowly Bills last week. That'll work.
Michael Thomas continues to establish himself as one of the top wide receivers in the NFL, after racking up 12 catches and two touchdowns in a win over Cleveland last week.
The Cowboys' defense looks formidable. In last week's win over the Giants, rookie running back Saquon Barkley managed just 28 rushing yards on 11 carries.
The 1-1 Bears will have a chance to start a winning streak on Sunday when they play one of the worst teams in the NFL, the Arizona Cardinals.
The 49ers are not winless, but they did just barely skate by a thoroughly mediocre Lions team at home. The jury is still out on San Francisco.
Baltimore's defense couldn't stop Cincinnati last week. The Ravens need linebacker C.J. Mosley (bone bruise) to return, and soon.
Ben Roethlisberger threw 60 times last week. That's an offense that misses Le'Veon Bell.
The Titans topped the Texans last week despite being outgained by 154 yards and forcing zero turnovers. It's hard to believe the better team won.
The Colts' defense held Washington to just 65 rushing yards and nine points last week. It'll be hard to replicate that performance against the Eagles on Sunday.
Through two games, rookie quarterback Sam Darnold has completed 66.1 percent of his passes, throwing for three touchdowns and three interceptions.
Zane Gonzalez missed two field goals and two extra points against the Saints last week, essentially costing the Browns the game. Unsurprisingly, Gonzalez is now a free agent.
The Seahawks need to get Bobby Wagner, K.J. Wright and Doug Baldwin back from injury. They also desperately need a win in their home opener against Dallas.
The Texans are 0-2. But at least they've got Will Fuller, who returned from an injury to catch eight passes for 113 yards and a touchdown last week.
Washington is 1-1, but things could go south in a hurry. Its next four games are against Green Bay, New Orleans, Carolina and Dallas.
The Raiders are 0-2, but they've got a chance to rebound with upcoming games against Miami and Cleveland.
Eli Manning was sacked six times last week and Saquon Barkley ran for just 28 yards. Not exactly how they drew it up.
Detroit hired a renowned defensive coordinator as its head coach, then promptly allowed 78 points in its first two games. Figures.
The bad news is that the Cardinals have scored a total of six points in their first two games and Sam Bradford is averaging a staggering four yards per attempt. There is no good news.
Bills cornerback Vontae Davis retired at halftime last week. And really, can you blame him?
The Rams have outscored their opponents 102-36 in their three wins. They'll have a challenge at home on Sunday against Minnesota's defense.
Patrick Mahomes has completed 66.7 percent of his passes, throwing 13 touchdown passes and zero interceptions. Safe to say the Chiefs have moved on from Alex Smith.
The Dolphins are 3-0 for the first time since 2013. They lost their next four games that season. They'll try to buck that trend in New England on Sunday.
Carson Wentz is officially back from a torn ACL. Can that addition spark the Eagles' offense?
Drew Brees threw for 396 yards and three touchdowns last weekend and ran for two more scores. The 39-year-old quarterback doesn't seem to be slowing down.
The Titans allowed just six points to Jacksonville last weekend and got quarterback Marcus Mariota back from injury. Next comes a test against the Super Bowl champion Eagles.
The Jaguars thumped the Patriots and then scored six points in a loss to the Titans. It's hard to know what to make of Jacksonville at this point.
The Fitzmagic ran out on Monday Night Football, as Ryan Fitzpatrick's three interceptions effectively sank the Buccaneers.
Hello, Adrian Peterson. The veteran running back has reignited himself to the tune of 236 rushing yards, 4.2 yards per carry and three touchdowns in three games.
Call it the Khalil Mack effect if you want to, but the 2-1 Bears lead the NFL with 14 sacks in three games.
Christian McCaffrey continues to be the focal point of the Panthers' offense, with 194 total yards in a win over the Bengals last weekend.
The Ravens' pass defense has been a menace so far, rankings second in the NFL in opposing passer rating (67.6).
The jury is out on quarterback Case Keenum, who has thrown more interceptions (5) than touchdowns (3) and hasn't thrown a TD pass since the season opener.
Andy Dalton threw four interceptions in a loss to the Panthers last week. The Bengals hit the road to take on the Falcons on Sunday.
How exactly did the Vikings get throttled at home by Josh Allen and the winless Bills? Days later, the answer is still a mystery.
Despite a lingering knee injury, quarterback Aaron Rodgers has thrown for 832 yards with six touchdowns and zero interceptions.
The Browns picked up their first win last week since Dec. 24, 2016. They can start a winning streak on Sunday against the Oakland Raiders.
Ben Roethlisbeger had a prolific performance on Monday night, throwing for 353 yards with three touchdowns and an interception. The Steelers are going to need him.
What's going on here? The Patriots fell to the winless Detroit Lions last weekend. Not they'll have to contend with the undefeated Miami Dolphins.
Matt Ryan's 374 passing yards and five touchdowns weren't enough in a loss to the New Orleans Saints. The Falcons will hope to rebound against the Bengals on Sunday.
The Chargers lost the battle of Los Angeles to the Rams last weekend. Maybe now they'll wise up and move back to San Diego.
The Seahawks have a real opportunity to mount a winning streak, with the 0-3 Cardinals next on the schedule. But will Earl Thomas make the trip to Phoenix?
The Bills dominated the Vikings last weekend, because life is meaningless and nothing makes sense.
Matt Patricia's defense finally woke up in a win over his former team, the Patriots, last weekend. Now it gets to feed on the Cowboys' struggling offense.
Dak Prescott has passed for just 145 yards per game and has just two touchdown passes to his name. Good luck naming the Cowboys' starting wide receivers.
Eli Manning completed 86.2 percent of his passes in a win over the Texans last weekend, which tells you all you need to know about the Texans' secondary.
The Jets lost to the Browns and a quarterback making the first appearance of his NFL career. The clock is ticking for Todd Bowles.
The good news is that Andrew Luck is back. The bad news is that he averaged just 4.1 yards per attempt against the Eagles.
Jimmy Garoppolo's season is over because of a torn ACL. And guess what? The 49ers' season is essentially over, too.
The Texans have been outscored 55-19 in the first half this season. And yet, all three of their losses were one-score games.
Jon Gruden's Raiders are 0-3 and that Monday Night Football booth is looking cozier by the minute.
The Cardinals rank dead last in scoring offense, with 20 total points in three games. Good luck, Josh Rosen.
The Rams are undefeated and lead the NFL in total offense. Next up: a Seahawks secondary without Earl Thomas.
The Chiefs passed their first serious test of 2018, overcoming a 10-point fourth-quarter deficit to defeat the Broncos and remain undefeated.
Doubt if you must, but the Titans have topped the Jaguars and Eagles in back-to-back weeks. Better yet, they meet the hopeless Bills on Sunday.
No surprise here, but the Jaguars lead the NFL in scoring defense and total defense. If Blake Bortles doesn't self-destruct, they win.
Alvin Kamara had 181 total yards and three touchdowns last weekend, and the Saints now get Mark Ingram back from suspension. That offense is scary.
Mitch Trubisky threw for 354 yards and six (!) touchdowns last weekend. Are the Bears that good, or are the Bucs that bad?
Washington ranks second in the NFL in scoring defense and third in total defense. That defense will be tested against the Saints on Monday night.
The Bengals lost tight end Tyler Eifert last weekend but continue to get huge contributions from wide receiver Tyler Boyd, who caught 11 passes against the Falcons.
The Ravens won in Pittsburgh last week and travel to Cleveland on Sunday with a chance to pull ahead in the AFC North.
On the heels of a bye week, newly-signed safety Eric Reid will make his Panthers debut in a home game against the Giants on Sunday.
The Dolphins' undefeated season was harpooned by the Patriots last week. Now it's up to Ryan Tannehill and Co. to pick up the pieces against two potential playoff teams in Cincinnati and Chicago.
The Packers have winnable games against the Lions and 49ers on the horizon. Their playoff hopes continue to rest on Aaron Rodgers' arm (and knee).
Have the mighty Patriots awoken from their slumber? We'll find out when 2-2 New England hosts a former rival in the Colts on Thursday night.
Something is missing in Philadelphia. The good news is that wide receiver Alshon Jeffrey returned and produced eight catches for 105 yards and a touchdown in last week's loss to the Titans.
The Broncos won their first two games by a comined four points and have since lost two straight. Things are trending downward in Denver,

The Chargers eked past the 49ers last weekend, no thanks to placekicker Caleb Sturgis, who missed two extra points and a field goal attempt. In other words, the Chargers may be in the market for a kicker.
The good news? The Seahawks have won two consecutive games. The bad news? They now run into the Rams without arguably their best player in Earl Thomas.
The Cowboys needed a last-second field goal to drop Detroit last weekend. Running back Ezekiel Elliott ripped off 240 total yards and a touchdown in the win.
Well, the Fitzmagic is officially gone. After two consecutive losses, the Bucs limp into the bye week with a decision to make regarding its starting quarterback.
Whatever happened to that vaunted Vikings defense? That group ranks 21st in total defense and 22nd in scoring defense. They meet Philadelphia on Sunday in a game both teams need to win.
The Browns have tied one game and lost two more by a total of six points. Still, nearly winning doesn't count for much in the NFL.
The Steelers were shut out in the second half of a home loss to division rival Baltimore last week. The LeVeon-less Steelers ran for a total of 19 yards on the night.
The Texans needed overtime to secure their first win of the season, over the Indianapolis Colts. Quarterback Deshaun Watson threw for 375 yards and two touchdowns and ran for another score.
Dan Quinn's once-mighty Falcons defense has allowed 80 points in its last two games. Even Matt Ryan, Julio Jones and Calvin Ridley can't close that gap.
Andrew Luck broke out against the Texans, passing 62 times for 464 yards and four touchdowns. But the Colts still lost, because they're the Colts.
The Lions have beaten the Patriots and lost to the Jets, 49ers and Cowboys, who own a combined 1-8 record against the rest of the NFL. That was a confusing sentence.
The 49ers are 0-1 in the C.J. Beathard Era this season. Without injured quarterback Jimmy Garoppolo, Beathard threw for 298 yards with two touchdowns and two interceptions against the Chargers.
Like the Texans, the Raiders needed overtime to beat a bad team and secure their first win. And like the Texans, the Raiders are not very good.
Maybe the Giants have just gotten a tough early draw, with two of their three losses coming against the Jaguars and Saints. It won't get much easier with a road game at Carolina on Sunday.
The Jets have averaged 13.7 points per game in their three consecutive losses. That's no surprise with a rookie quarterback (Sam Darnold) and few proven offensive weapons.
The Bills were shut out in Green Bay last weekend and Josh Allen completed less than half of his passes and threw two interceptions. It's going to be a bumpy ride.
The bottom three teams in these power rankings are starting rookie quarterbacks. Can that be a coincidence? Probably not.
